Introduction

Food protein-induced allergic proctocolitis (FPIAP) is a benign, nonâ€“IgE-mediated reaction in young infants that is triggered by dietary proteins (eg, casein, whey) found in standard formula and/or breast milk.  It is characterized by blood-streaked stools in otherwise healthy infants and managed by dietary elimination of the offending protein.

Pathogenesis



FPIAP is a benign, self-limited, nonâ€“IgE-mediated reaction that occurs in infancy.  The exact mechanism is unclear but is likely due to a delayed-type hypersensitivity to dietary proteins that may be exaggerated due to an immature neonatal intestinal barrier, allowing increased antigen absorption.  Eosinophilic infiltration of the distal colon and rectum results in mucosal friability and rectal bleeding.



The most common dietary triggers are cow's milk proteins (eg, casein, whey); other proteins (eg, egg, soy, corn) are less frequently implicated.  Cow's milk proteins are found in standard formula preparations as well as breast milk when the maternal diet includes dairy products.  Although the maternal intestinal tract hydrolyzes some cow's milk protein, a portion is only partially hydrolyzed and excreted in breast milk.

Clinical presentation



The typical presentation involves an infant age 2-8 weeks with painless, blood-streaked stools that may be loose and contain mucus.  Because symptoms of FPIAP are insidious and develop weeks to months after initial exposure to the offending food protein, symptoms may initially develop as late as age 6 months.  Patients may have some associated fussiness but are generally well-appearing with normal growth and a normal examination (ie, no abdominal tenderness or distension, no anal fissures).  A minority of patients have concomitant eczema or a family history of atopy.



Symptoms suggestive of a different diagnosis include fever, failure to thrive, profuse diarrhea, and forceful vomiting.

Differential diagnosis



  • Anal fissure:  The most common cause of rectal bleeding in infants is constipation with an associated anal fissure, which would be visible on examination.  History would reveal straining with bowel movements, hard stools without mucus, and blood on the outside of the stool (not mixed within it).
  • Intussusception (
    figure 1
    ):  This condition classically presents at age 6-36 months with intermittent, colicky abdominal pain (or fussiness in an infant), and vomiting.  Hematochezia is a late sign and indicates bowel ischemia in an ill-appearing patient.
  • Infectious colitis:  Bloody stools can be caused by certain enteric infections (eg, Salmonella, Shigella), but fever and diarrhea are expected.
  • Meckel diverticulum:  A Meckel diverticulum contains heterotopic gastric mucosa that secretes hydrochloric acid in the distal ileum, causing intestinal ulceration and bleeding.  Painless, bloody stools are common in older children, but presentation is rare at age <6 months and typically involves an ill-appearing infant with abdominal pain and lethargy due to associated complications (eg, intussusception, intestinal obstruction).
  • Food proteinâ€“induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  This severe, nonâ€“IgE-mediated reaction to cow's milk proteins or other foods leads to inflammation of the entire large and small bowel.  Acute episodes typically present with profuse vomiting within 4 hours of food allergen ingestion, followed by diarrhea (with or without blood), lethargy, and dehydration.  Moreover, patients with FPIES often have poor weight gain and are ill-appearing when symptomatic.
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) (
    figure 2
    ):  NEC, or hemorrhagic necrosis of the bowel wall, is a gastrointestinal emergency that most commonly occurs in premature infants.  In addition to rectal bleeding, patients often have abdominal distension, poor feeding, and hemodynamic instability.
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD):  IBD is an extremely rare diagnosis in infants that can manifest with bloody stools.  However, associated findings typically include diarrhea, fever, and weight loss.

Diagnosis



FPIAP is a clinical diagnosis based on characteristic findings of a well-appearing young infant with painless, blood-streaked stools.  The stool is often tested to confirm the presence of blood, a finding that supports the diagnosis but is nonspecific.



Other laboratory tests (eg, complete blood count, stool culture) and imaging (abdominal x-ray) are not required unless atypical features (eg, ill appearance, vomiting, severe diarrhea) suggestive of an alternative diagnosis are present.  In such cases, flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy with biopsy may also be considered.



Biopsy findings consistent with FPIAP include mucosal inflammation and eosinophilic infiltration confined to the distal colon and rectum.  Histopathologic findings include infiltration of eosinophils within the lamina propria and muscularis mucosa.

Management



Treatment for FPIAP is dietary elimination of the presumed offending protein (

figure 3
), which is most commonly cow's-milk protein:



  • Breastfed infants:  Management of breastfed infants is through maternal dietary elimination of dairy products.  Sequential maternal elimination of other potential allergens (eg, soy, egg) is reserved for infants with persistent symptoms to avoid a significantly restrictive maternal diet.
  • Formula-fed infants:  Infants taking cow's milk formula should be switched to a hydrolyzed formula, in which the allergenic cow's milk proteins (eg, casein) are broken down and no longer antigenic.  In rare cases, an amino acidâ€“based (elemental) formula that contains no intact proteins may be required.  Switching from cow's milkâ€“based formula to soy-based formula is not recommended due to potential cross-reactivity between cow's milk and soy proteins.


With dietary elimination of the offending food protein, blood-streaked stools typically resolve within a few days (up to 2 weeks), which confirms the diagnosis; repeat Hemoccult testing for microscopic blood is not typically required.  Due to the inadvertent maternal consumption of a product containing cow's milk, breastfed infants may experience occasional symptom relapse (eg, blood-streaked stools).



Flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy with biopsy may be considered when FPIAP does not respond as expected to dietary changes.

Prognosis



FPAIP has an excellent prognosis with no long-term sequelae because almost all affected infants can tolerate products containing the offending protein (eg, milk, yogurt, soy) by age 1 when gradual reintroduction of such foods is recommended.



There is a slightly increased risk of developing IgE-mediated food allergy.

Summary



Food protein-induced allergic proctocolitis (

) is a benign, nonâ€“IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to dietary proteins, primarily cow's milk.  Classic presentation involves a well-appearing young infant with painless, bloody stools.  Diagnosis is clinical, and management involves eliminating dairy from the maternal diet (if breastfeeding) or switching to a hydrolyzed formula.  Most infants outgrow the condition by age 1.
